comments.text:
after testing 6 9070 card's i can say most wont do -75mv game stable in all games. Some games seem stable other that will boost higer to 3100MHz will crash. Its hard to test them well. SteelNomad is a good stability test but its heavy so it will test lower boost clocks only. 
What i did is max out power for that test. Check for max stability and what the max boost clock was and then limit the card to that boost clock most of the time you would need -500MHz or -450MHz offset to get that done.But you will limit performance a bit since the card will now only boost to 2850-2900MHz. The up side is that its way way more efficient. RDNA4 does not scale well performance wise above 3GHz and it needs a lot of extra power.

I prefer to run My Gigabyte 9070 XT OC @ -320Core offset -45mv 2746MHz Memory with Fast Timings and only a 240watt power target that way i get close to stock 304watt XT performance but at a very nice reduction of power. And in some games hitting max boost it will only use 200-220watt instead of pulling the whole 330 it would normally do by boosting to 3150-3200MHz. Now max boost is at 3020-3050MHz There are a lot of cases where it can only boost to 2750-2850 but adding 50 watt of extra power (With no limit it would use 290w in that scenario) only gave me 185MHz extra clock and 123fps instead of 119 so it was not worth it to me.

comments.text: The problem with the AMD cards is that they will always fall behind in AI features, driver refinement etc. etc... Although it looks like they are doing great in those graphs, performance plummets when you turn on RT for example. DLSS, frame gen and game optimization by NVIDIA is also always going to be better with more improvements to come. A little bit of better raw performance is not enough of a reason for me to get a GPU. Because at the end of the day, competitive gaming will run well on either but for single player games, you'd want the best visuals, meaning RT on, DLSS on and all the extras. This is why this time I decided to go for an RTX 5070 instead of the 9070XT, which saved me money that went for a CPU instead. Although AMD has come a long way in terms of software, my experience when I had the RX6800 was mixed. Sometimes driver updates would cause my games crashing. I ran into such problems a bit too often owning the card for only about a year and a half. On the other hand, my RTX 4060 laptop never had a problem with drivers. There's a level of refinement that NVIDIA is able to achieve that AMD cannot. Don't get me wrong, I respect AMD's competitive positioning, but I do feel like YouTube reviewers are hyping up AMD a bit too much lately. In real world use, NVIDIA still has an edge.
comments.author: @papafilstef

comments.text:
I could be wrong and this is really not anything important but I believe you said your percentages wrong 2:55
From your baseline you are correct to say that it beats the 7900GRE by around 19% (its 19% faster)
Same with saying the 5070, saying the 9070 by around 4% faster
But it is not 10.5% slower with 7900xtx because that implies the baseline is the 7900xtx and the percentage of 9070 would be 98.97% if it were true, it's actually 9.57% slower than the xtx, it would easier to say the xtx is 10.5% faster, 
9070Xt is 17.24% faster than the 9070, but the 9070 would be 14.7% slower than 9070xt
and with the 5080 it is 37.68% faster than the 9070, but the 9070 would be 27.36% slower than 5080

Hope this didn't come off as rude, just nice to know that the way you say it might change what baseline you are referring to

comments.text:
Just a brief note on mathematics semantics. As a single example of where you were 'technically' going awry: at 3:18 we can see that the 5080 is indeed 37.68% FASTER than the 9070, BUT the 9070 is NOT, therefore, 37.68% slower!
(Good news, it's only actually 27.37% slower.) Similarly, the 7900XTX is 10.59% faster than the 9070; BUT the 9070 is only 9.57% SLOWER than a freaking 9700XTX!! Not bad at all.
On a related note, while the 37% figure quoted at 4:06 was not incorrect, as the 5080 is indeed this much FASTER; using the maths the other way around, as per above, the 9070XT is only actually 27% SLOWER than the 5080 in Black Myth Wukong! Also, not freaking bad.
Anyway, just thought i'd slip that one in while no-one was looking.

comments.text:
Just went from an RTX 3090 to the Aorus Elite variant of the 9070 XT. I couldn't be more happier - I play games at 4K, and the performance increase is more substantial than I initially expected. I chose to go with AMD this time because of FSR 4, and their price to performance compared to Nvidia, which is *price before performance*. 

I wanted to go for a 5090 if the price was around the same as my 3090 at launch 5 years ago.. here in Norway it doubled, and not only that - Nvidia's been presenting more problems than gaming performance with the 5000 series.. So to me, currently AMD is the winner in this launch cycle of GPUs. FSR 4 looks really good too and does a really good job at reconstructing the image to 4K even at performance. 

All I can say is that the 9070 XT is nothing to scoff at and can definitely do 4K gaming just fine. It can do rasterization just fine, but if you want a higher fps, FSR 4 works really well and it's hard to notice the difference between native and upscaled. Upscaled can sometimes even look a bit better due to the aliasing it can reduce with upscaling. 
 I prefer playing with upscaling for higher framerates, and I'm glad FSR 4 is as good as it is for AMD's first attempt at competing with Nvidia's DLSS with their own AI upscaling.

Worth the money, even if you're on a 3090 imo - it's definitely not a necessary upgrade, but if you want to upgrade to something newer that doesn't cost you your soul, the 9070 XT is a good choice for a decent uplift in performance.
comments.author: @CruciallyUltrawide

The 9070 XT is a great card, I heavily considered it. Though I ultimately settled for a 5070 Ti that I got for almost MSRP. Point being I do more than gaming, I edit video in DaVinci Resolve and the new media engines of the 5070 Ti completely leave my old 4070 in the dust when encoding AV1/H.265. Literally cuts rendering time by A LOT. A rendering time of 30 minutes on my old card might be 7 to 8 minutes on my new card, it's utterly insane what the performance difference is. 

I also like to run local AI models on my PC, and nVidia is just so far ahead in that department. As for gaming, my 5070 Ti overclocks well, I got it close to stock 5080 performance relatively easily. It can go toe to toe with even an overclocked 9070 XT, with it coming out ahead in heavy ray tracing/path tracing games every time.

comments.text:
@jonorgames6596  That is wrong. 
Yes, the 5080 is, in terms of used die capacity more a 5060, but in the end it is still a 1500€+ high-end 4k gaming card. It being 'mid-range' is only in a gen by gen comparison between nvidia cards. All in all, the 5080 is the top-level gaming/consumer card in the nvidia protfolio. The 5090 is a professional/prosumer card that has abysmal uplift in regards to consumer usage, that card is only for people that make money off of it and those that can't purchase a Porsche/Lambo/[insert midlife crisis buy of your choice] for their dangly parts extension. 
Nvidia is not really better, Nvidia has just monopolized the market through proprietary software solutions, like CUDA and currently on the cancer that is DLSS. From a user perspective outside of gaming, AMD often wasn't an option because lots of software is optimized for the proprietary solutions instead of the FOSS solutions. 
How well those practices age for the consumer we're very much seeing with PhysX 32 Bit. I mean, what a time to be alive - new gen performing worse than 15 year old cards because they killed the support of their proprietary excrement. Nvidia told us a few things through that: 
1. You better get a few 30xx or 40xx series cards in reserve stock if you want to be able to play games from today in 10 years or so. 
2. Their hardware performance depends on their proprietary software solutions, which they will cancel whenever they see fit, i. e. the second they don't make money off of it anymore. Hardware that depends on more software to run than the drivers is bad hardware. 
3. All the current 'AI' uplift will be history when AI inevitably dies off, resulting in 5000 series cards being worse than their predecessors. 

The next thing is, AMD already told us, way before release, they wouldn't try to compete in the 'high-end' i. e. they didn't try to compete in the prosumer market with the 5090, so the reality of it is: The 750€ 9070XT is as powerful as the 1500€ Nvidia competition (checked prices just now for available cards) and a perfectly fine 4k gaming card - which in my book classifies as high-end, not mid-range. I mean, you tell me what more you want from a gaming GPU other than highest resolution maximum graphic settings while having a fluid experience FPS-wise. low-end, mid-range, high-end should be thought of as levels of capabilities, not in form of product line-ups. 
low-end would currently be a 1080p high settings / 1440p low/mid settings gaming card. 
mid-range would be around 1440p highest settings to 4k low settings. 
high-end would be anything beyond. 

And all of those levels should absolutely disregard upscaling tech, because that's only as good as the server farm used to train the AI on those games. The second the AI hype dies, which won't be too far off since its expensive and delivers worse quality in most scenarios where companies tried to implement it, the servers that train DLSS for individual games will be history. There is a space for AI, but its very limited in comparison to what its used for today.

comments.text: AMD cards aren't good for any content creation where CUDA acceleration is the primary accelerator. Or NVENC encoding is the primary method. AMD's software is still second-class for these things.
comments.author: @UFDTech

comments.text: they're okay for streaming now because they have most of the encoders (including full AV1 encode/decode as of every 7000 and 9000 card except for the 7600 and 7600XT), but as far as editing, Nvidia's CUDA cores take the crown. CUDA is king and AMD hasnt had an alternative for at least a decade now. AMD will still work on those apps, but CUDA is generally a lot faster, because like 98% of editing and rendering apps, including Blender, are built around CUDA software libraries. This is why people often recommend AMD to people who are just rasterized gaming, and Nvidia for content creation mixed with ray traced or highly demanding games.

comments.text: @mort996 Enjoy your new GPU. However, you may want to consider keeping your old gpu as a frame gen card if needed using Lossless scaling.  I have had my 3080 12GB for years and use it w/ an almost 4k monitor (5120x1440), but have never gotten close to the 240Hz refresh rate even w/ DLSS in most games. However, w/ an old 6700XT 12GB it should be possible to max out the refresh rate at the cost of a little latency and artifacts. Vram wise Cyberpunk can push the memory usage close to 12BG depending on RT settings and Indiana Jones can use over 12GB as well, but most games will be under 12GB for now and you will have a great experience. For my old eyes it is hard to see the difference between DLSS performance and quality at 4k unless looking at hairs, etc., but I prefer the higher frame rate most days. Even these old eyes can see a difference between 70 and 100Hz. I also thought about selling the 6700XT since the 3080 chugs along w/ most games, the experience is good, and frame gen is not "needed", but I am still a geek at heart & playing around w/ duel GPU setup in 2025 seems fun/nostalgic.
comments.author: @denlog1177

comments.text:
@ Hahaa, ja sam bio ubeđen da sam jedini ludak koji prati ove tech kanale. Benchmark je postao toliko jadan, da ono, ne znam... Onaj ćelavi što im radi recenzije za pc hardware je toliko antipatična glava... Probao sam da odgledam njegov review 5070 i 5070ti, kontam da je jedini na svetu koji je ishvalio te karte. Još se lik svađa u komentarima i ubeđuje ljude da nisu normalni što očekuju generacijski skok performansi, nego čestita lopurdama na "hrabrosti" što su grunuli MFG🙄
Što se tiče ćacija, ne mogu više da ćutim. Ranije sam iz pristojnosti ćutao nekim matorim ljudima sa kojima sarađujem, ali kad ti čovek iz struke kaže kako jeste bio javašluk na železničkoj stanicu, ali Žvalson gradi bolnice, puteve i daje im penzije, stvarno izgubim živce.
Što se tiče polovnog hardvera, razumem ljude koji se plaše, pogotovo zbog majnera, ali brate mili, uvek možeš da istestiraš grafu, pogledaš da nije prašnjava, ne miriše čudno, da nema korozije na IO shield-u i da čip nije spečen. Ja sam iskreno uzeo od nekog majnera 3080ti, doneo mi je čovek 5-6 komada da istestiram i prva za koju sam se uhvatio je bila ok i radila je perfektno dok se nisam zeznuo i prodao je. Pre nje sam imao gtx 1070 koju sam nešto kobajagi modovao, zamenio sam joj stock kuler nekim Arcticom i psovao sam samog sebe i preznojavao se, pošto mi je to bila ekstra skupa karta tad i tripovao sam se da sam je polomio, ali je operacija bila ekstra - gpu je bio skroz tih i temp oko 50-60, a sa stock je bila 80C i drala se ko Karleuša :)
Ovde realno fali ljudi koji bi radili te stvari. Imaš par onih gejmera koji odrade recenzije i to je to. Eventualno onaj Pejić priča o KP varijantama, ali iz nekog razloga mi je taj dečko postao antipatičan.
P.S. Uzdravlje da te služi grafa 🍻 Ozbiljna je to zverka i dalje, po mom mišljenju je bolja od 3090, jer se manje greje
comments.author: @markomarkovic5729

comments.text: @markomarkovic5729  sve se apsolutno slažem, vidi se da isto razmišljamo. Pazi, realno gledano ti ako ljudima preporučuješ kp faktički podstičeš sivu ekonomiju, ali po meni mnogo je više podstiču naše prodavnice i nenormalne marže koje stavljaju na robu da je ovo što mi robu nabavljamo od Mađara kap u moru u odnosu na sistemske probleme koje imamo u državi, dok se sistem ne promeni iz korena nemam apsolutno nikakvu želju da podstičem našu ekonomiju, dovoljno je što donosim pare iz strane firme u zemlju i trošim na naše prehrambene proizvode i ostalo. Što se tiče benchmarking kanala nisam nešto preterano istraživao naše, za taj Benchmark znam igrom slučaja jer sam slao drugaru koji ne zna engleski a tražio je novi tv pa mu poslao da pogleda neku moju preporuku, za kompove sam video da izbacuju na forumu ali to je smejurija što ti kažeš. Drugo što me nervora je što niko ne uzima u obzir realne cene ovde u Srbiji i nema m*da da kaže alo bre, pa jel realno da plaćaš deo 800-900e koji bi trebao da košta 500e, kao da se boje da im neko ne zakuca na vrata ili nešto. Ja ću ovako solo brt da izbacujem klipove jer me zabole baš, niti imam svoju firmu niti imam šta da mažem ljude, što se kaže čovek iz naroda pa će verovatno i prijati ljudima malo svežine a ne prosipanje priče. Što se polovne grafe tiče, realno gledano 3000 serija Nvidie je 99% majnovala i tu nema šta, otvoriću je ja svakako, zameniću pastu i proveriti ventilatore i die dal je okej, u suštini gledao sam dosta videa gde ljudi namerno uzimaju majnovane kartice da pokažu da nije u suštini uopšte problem što su majnovale, tebi grafa može da nastrada na hiljadu načina kako god okreneš

comments.text: Undervolting reduces power consumption while still maintaining relatively the same performance. Lower heat generation will allow the card to go more full out, but if the card is already going full out then you won't see much gain. For me personally, I undervolt to keep my energy bill down as I like having a RX 9070 XT but 97% performance with -25% power draw is a nice trade-off. And I have a RTX 3060 12G Gaming OC to go with it for CUDA stuff like in Lightroom or CUDA/PhysX32-favoring games.
